note.body:
I don't think it's the number of rows.  I pass the words from the file as a linked list of "Word" structs, then iterate through the words and add them to the tree store.  The columns are created and named after that.

If I take a small block of text and cut and paste it over and over again until I have a huge file, it works fine.  But there appears to be a finite number of unique "Word" structs it can add to the tree store before the column headers disappear.  This even though the parse algorithm is not failing.

events.target_title: WIP: Wayland surface fullscreen unredirect

note.body:
Note that generally all buffers sent by a client (for the same surface size) should have the same properties relevant for scanout. Therefore, something like this could work:

* When a client sends a buffer which could be scanned out directly in principle, start recording these properties until it sends the same buffer a second time.
* If the recorded properties allow for flipping between these buffers, start direct scanout.
* If the client buffers differ from the compositor's own buffers in any of these properties, transitions between compositor & client buffers can be done with a modeset instead of a flip. (If both buffers contain the same visible contents, the modeset shouldn't be detectable by the user)

Sorry for the noise if it's already working like that. :)

events.target_title: WIP: Wayland surface fullscreen unredirect

note.body:
> Doesn't a mode set ala drmModeSetCrtc() block until it's finished?

It does. As long as there's no change in the mode timings, the kernel driver should only need to program the new buffer address / pitch / ..., which should be quick.

Hmm, though there might still be visible artifacts in some cases, e.g. if one of the buffers uses colour compression but the other does not. Might need to get feedback from kernel driver folks.

> We use that when page flipping failed due to broken/old drivers.

My point is that this should generally only happen when transitioning between compositor and client buffers, not while flipping between client buffers.

events.target_title: More inverting options
More inverting options

note.body:
I already have GIMP 2.80.x.

Let's say 008000, which has a brightness of 0.4305874572152616. Another layer in the same place has a pixel of FFFFFF, which has a brightness of 1.0. This means that the color 008000 has to be multiplied by 1.0÷0.4305874572152616=2.322408568208885. Multiplying 008000 by 2.322408568208885 makes it 00FF00. Therefore 008000 is brought to the brightness of FFFFFF (well, not quite, because of RGB limits). Now imagine that done with every single pixel in both layers. How can I do that with layers? (something like Y inversion in YCbCr won't work, because it will ADD the appropriate amount in RGB to the desired brightness, not MULTIPLY the appropriate amount; for example brightening 008000 could result in 7FFF7F instead of 00FF00; also, YCbCr has an inferior brightness function as opposed to `(0.212671×R^2.2+0.71516×G^2.2+0.072169×B^2.2)^0.4545454545454546`)

events.target_title: More inverting options

note.body:
"There is no GIMP 2.80.x, only GIMP 2.8.x."

WHAT THE HECK ARE YOU TALKING ABOUT?! That's not how math works. http://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=2.80+%3D+2.8

In the example image, I suppose you are trying to simulate HSV hue inversion. I can't tell if GIMP did it precisely though, because you lossily compressed it with JPG. Also, you said you used some legacy mode, which means that a feature you used is actually from an even older version than 2.1! (that's probably why you told me to downgrade from 2.8 to 2.1 — in newer versions some of the legacy features may have been removed)

You still didn't simulate any brightness or hue shift algorithms that use visual brightness with the algorithm `0.212671×R^2.2+0.71516×G^2.2+0.072169×B^2.2)^0.4545454545454546`, and MULTIPLYING to the target brightness as opposed to ADDING.

In examples, it would be helpful to use the attached image for testing effects. It will help me debug various color manipulation algorithms easier.

![colorsamplehuge](/uploads/1b0be931076510d11f7c97b6b1cf036c/colorsamplehuge.PNG)

events.target_title: Functions for Green and Blue check boxes are swapped in Convolution Matrix dialog box
Gimp layer mode Addition calculates vector magnitude instead
Gimp layer mode Addition calculates vector magnitude instead

note.body: It's fine if you want to create a new layer mode called Magnitude, and use this formula, but it shouldn't be called addition. Addition should be the way that it always has been in older versions of Gimp. With addition, it should always be Output = Value1 + Value2

events.target_title: Gimp layer mode Addition calculates vector magnitude instead

note.body: Maybe there should be separate Addition and Linear Addition blending modes. Adding in perceptual space (not linear space), is typically what is done, even in Photoshop's version of Addition mode (which Photoshop calls Linear Dodge).

events.target_title: .gitattributes diff filters are not respected when viewing diffs

note.body:
Another use-case is [nbstripout](https://github.com/kynan/nbstripout). The notebook files it processes contain a mix of code snippets and their output, including rendered figures as base64 strings. Nbstripout filters these outputs (which can be regenerated) and exposes only the code to git.
Since notebooks contain code, being able to browse their diffs without the cluttering of binary dumps in the middle would be nice.

events.target_title: Surface Pen - switching from stylus tip to eraser then back to tip causes crash.
Support for animated png (apng)
More inverting options

note.body:
@PiotrGrocowski Hi, I see you're a bit lost and suspicious. Generally, when you are suspicious about any website related to a program or the replies you get, the good reflex is to go back to the official website of the program in question and find your way from there.

For gimp, the official website is gimp.org

If you go there and click on Participate (in the top bar), then on "bugs" (under Bug Reports), then on "open issues (all)", you will be brought back here, which confirms that this is the official bug reporting website.

If you go back on gimp.org and click on Download on the top bar, you'll see that the latest version is indeed 2.10.

You should read this short wikipedia paragraph to understand how versioning works:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_versioning#Incrementing_sequences

I hope you'll be able to fix your issue and have lots of fun with GIMP.

events.target_title: Serious performance degradation of moving layer within a group beyond boundaries of other layers or canvas edge
Can't use eraser in floating pasted unanchored item (2.8 -> 2.10 regression)

note.body:
When you paste something, look at the layers panel with the floating layer selected. There's a set of "Lock" options there, and one is "Lock alpha channel". This is on by default in 2.10 (at least, it is for me) and this will prevent you from erasing. If you toggle this off, you can erase your new floating layer.

The switch to 2.10 has been tough for me because defaults have changed that I didn't even know existed. It makes it hard to differentiate a changed default and a bug. Maybe changes to defaults like this ARE a bug?

GNU Image Manipulation Program version 2.10.2
Warn/catch KVM access issues
Gnome-Boxes

note.body:
@aklapper Dupe of #215, #198, #200, (probably others), https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/gnome-boxes/+bug/1767302

When gnome-boxes is installed in Ubuntu, it does not automatically add the current user to the `kvm` user group, breaking the virtualisation.

**Fix**: `sudo adduser $USER kvm`

Boxes should be more specific about this issue (#225).

events.target_title: libenchant.dll missing from installers for Microsoft Windows platforms

note.body:
I ran into the same issue on a clean install of Gimp 2.10.4 (64 bit).  I did not have a problem with the libenchant.dll on the 2.10.2 release so I did a clean install of Gimp 2.10.2 and tested that. The error was gone. I installed Gimp 2.10.4 over top of Gimp 2.10.2 (not a clean install) and Gimp 2.10.4 is no longer giving me the missing libenchant.dll error.

This might be worth trying if those with these errors were done with "clean installs" or perhaps skipped previous Gimp 2.10 versions.

events.target_title: Move the 'Search and Run Command' to top menu bar

note.body:
Header bar could also be a solution.

Hitting '/' depends on what keyboard language setting is used. In the keyboard layout for my language, hitting '/' is not working and by trial and error, I found out it's actually 'Shift' + '/'. And that's the point - keyboard and shortcuts are not the same in every country and for every piece of software (or for every operating system) - and this is where a good UI can help.

Usually, there is an effort to place a searchbar on a visible location, because it doesn't make much sense to search for a searchbar (or keyboard shortcut to run in) in menus. 

Please don't take it as I'm complaining - I like GIMP, I like the 'Search and Run' feature, because it works pretty well. I'm just trying to suggest further improvements to make it even more useful :-)

events.target_title: No video playing in presentation mode

note.body:
PS
https://support.office.com/en-us/article/set-the-play-options-for-a-video-in-your-presentation-f0d5b3f1-37ba-4a0d-9d94-f8e33cef29bf
clearly says you're supposed to click on the video to start it. So at least they give the option to do so. If the authors don't want options (but hopefully they do have some, such as continuous scrolling...) they should at least pick the alternative which works... (remote controls buttons do page up/down)... I'm sorry to insist but this is so obvious, why make a presentation program unusable for ??% (90 in some fields) of the presentations?

events.target_title: No video playing in presentation mode

note.body:
*"Most other presentation software special-cases the presentation-mode mouse click, so a click inside the video plays it while a click outside advances the page. I'm not saying that behavior is ideal, but it is standard and does not lead to any extra options."*
Yes, this is what I have observed too. Which contradicts Gnome developers' statement "MS PowerPoint and LibreOffice Impress also have "click to advance", so that seems to be expected behavior for presentation software." (actually these CAN play embedded videos)
Strange...

events.target_title: No video playing in presentation mode

note.body:
I'm not sure I understand your answer. 
Evince is very nice to view any sort of documents but one should not be obliged to install okular or some other program for presentations. And it does not support presentations with embedded media. It is quite obviously an issue for many, isn't it(*). There are basically 3 solutions
- the simplest I assume is to consider that click means click (all laser pointers have buttons mapped to page-up page-down, so why would click mean page-down? to imitate MS Powerpoint which however does assume click means page-down only OUT of some embedded media and click INSIDE?);
- more complicated would be to imitate really MSPp's behaviour which depends on where the pointer is;
- far less satisfactory would be to have an option to let the user choose between page down and click.

But if one of these is not implemented it means many users MUST install another program, why is this *more* satisfactory than one of these 3? (It is hard for me to see why the first would require any programming, but I clearly might be wrong on this point.)

(*) of course there is another bug with embedded media I should file somewhere, but it is not the right place to describe it and I have first to check it is not a bug of beamer...

libpeas fails to build with Python 3.8
libpeas fails to build with Python 3.8

note.body:
This can be fixed by adding PYTHON3_LIBS=`${PYTHON3_CONFIG} --libs --embed` in configure.ac, however this is going to fail on earlier versions of python3.

A better fallback (but still a workaround, as it doesn't require to to regenerate everything, only the configure script), would be to encapsulate this [line](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/libpeas/blob/2f8b28dd8e1edc1bc3b05ef5379e4aa7d2876efb/configure.ac#L445) of configure.ac as such:


```
AC_PATH_PROGS(PYTHON38, [python3.8])  
    if test -n "${PYTHON38}"; then  
        PYTHON3_LIBS=`${PYTHON3_CONFIG} --libs --embed`  
    else  
        PYTHON3_LIBS=`${PYTHON3_CONFIG} --libs`  
    fi
```

events.target_title: Dialogs lose focus

note.body:
I have experienced this issue a lot on two different Macs; both 2.8 and 2.10 versions of GIMP. It has been problematic enough that I switched one of those Macs over to Ubuntu. (I have been using GIMP for about 20 years, and am not keen to learn something else just for macOS.)

I've attached a quicktime movie of the bug in action. A dialog pops up when I open a file, does not respond to clicks. To properly focus it I have to click away from GIMP and then back. It repros frequently, but not consistently and I know of no action that will guarantee to manifest the bug. The video below is against GIMP 2.10 a4 for macOS and was created June 29'th, 2018 a few hours after the build was available.

![bug](/uploads/2d60a81e6a04c6327bc3dd779d3806c3/bug.mov)

events.target_title: Startup error: 'twain.exe: The procedure entry point "FT_Done_MM_Var" could not be located in the DLL "C:\Program Files\GIMP 2\32\bin\libfontconfig-1.dll"'

note.body:
Hi Sylvie and thank you for your suggestions.

I tried uninstalling GIMP, deleting 'C:\program files\gimp 2' and installing it again (gimp-2.10.4-setup-2.exe from gimp.org).
Nothing changed (error message/scanner problem still present).

I then tried various custom installs. Unchecking 32-bit support completely during custom installation makes GIMP startup without any error messages. I also have the menu entry "File / Create / Scanner/Camera" back, but clicking on it doesn't have any effect. There is no scan dialogue window coming up (also not in the background). Although scanning using Abbyy Finereader or using the app "Epson Scan", saving the image and opening with GIMP of course still works without any problems, I would like to continue using GIMP's scan feature to import images directly.

I think my system configuration is nothing fancy. It's a two year old ThinkPad running on 64-bit Windows 10 attached to a relatively popular ca. six-year old Epson multi-function device model which is still present in many offices. I've used GIMP since version 2.2 on an old laptop running Ubuntu 7.04. Up to GIMP 2.8.x everything worked fine. I didn't have any startup errors and I could use my scanner/all-in-one device without any issues.

To sum up, I love GIMP - and I love the work and effort the developers have put into making GIMP 2.10 and finally making it compete again with other modern free or (very) expensive image editors. But I still think doing the standard install of the current GIMP version and getting startup error messages you always have to click away to finally start GIMP - or having to do a custom install leaving out 32-bit support, but still not being able to use the scan import feature anymore - is an unattractive bug.

events.target_title: Startup error: 'twain.exe: The procedure entry point "FT_Done_MM_Var" could not be located in the DLL "C:\Program Files\GIMP 2\32\bin\libfontconfig-1.dll"'

note.body:
Hi and thanks again for your help!

The twain_32.dll is present in my windows directory.

I can't scan from Microsoft Paint. My device is connected via ethernet, so I tried to connect it via USB, but Windows doesn't seem to have a WIA driver for it (cf. https://epson.com/faq/SPT_WIN10-NS~faq-283560?faq_cat=faq-topFaqs).

So, that means... I will only be able to scan via a WIA compatible device under Windows? Is there no way to make it use TWAIN anymore? That's a pity... but it seems to be a Windows/64-bit issue and you probably don't have these issues under Linux/Mac.
But it still would be nice to get rid of the error messages at program start if you don't uncheck 32-bit support in a custom install (which most users won't probably do).

BTW, am I missing some basic functionality if I didn't install GIMP with 32-bit support, or is this just important if I have some old plugins I want to continue using?

note.body:
Hi endolith, I don't know if this is the same problem - but it surely has to do with twain.exe and library conflicts as well.

I've now tested what Sylvie Alexandre suggested (thank you for your tips!). My WIA service could not be stopped until I restarted Windows fully. After restarting Windows I stopped and started the WIA service.

I also did what was suggested here: https://newsgroup.xnview.com/viewtopic.php?f=35&t=29630&sid=e910f155d7c6e67262ff0fa7ef8b5d30&start=30
In short: I deleted TWAIN.LOG, Twain001.Mtx, Twunk001.MTX and Twunk002.MTX under %SystemDrive%\Users\{username}\AppData\Local\Temp. (I don't know if this has had any effect).

I then checked if I can scan from inside Paint... and it works!

I then installed GIMP again with 32-bit support (full installation). Nothing changed. The startup error message is back and the menu point for creating an image from scanner is still missing :-(

So, I think I will now either delete the twain plugin files manually (C:\Program Files\GIMP 2\lib\gimp\2.0\plug-ins\twain.exe and ...\.debug\twain.exe.debug), or I will install GIMP again und uncheck 32-bit support.

What I still don't understand is why if I install GIMP without 32-bit support, the menu entry for creating an image from scanner is there (but doesn't open a windows when clicked).

:-(((

note.body:
## Gimp 2.8

This is the the result from Gimp 2.8 

Command+Scroll shows the same output as plain Scroll (first two events)
It seems that the system sends `shift + scroll left/right` instead of `shift + scroll` to GIMP

```
Received 'Mouse Wheel Events' (class 'Mouse Wheel')
    controller event 'scroll-up (Scroll Up)'
    (trigger event)
    maps to action 'view-zoom-out'
    action was found

Received 'Mouse Wheel Events' (class 'Mouse Wheel')
    controller event 'scroll-up (Scroll Up)'
    (trigger event)
    maps to action 'view-zoom-out'
    action was found

Received 'Mouse Wheel Events' (class 'Mouse Wheel')
    controller event 'scroll-down-alt (Scroll Down (⌥))'
    (trigger event)
    maps to action 'tools-value-1-increase-skip'
    action was found

Received 'Mouse Wheel Events' (class 'Mouse Wheel')
    controller event 'scroll-up-control (Scroll Up (⌃))'
    (trigger event)
    maps to action 'tools-paint-brush-size-increase'
    action was found

Received 'Mouse Wheel Events' (class 'Mouse Wheel')
    controller event 'scroll-left-shift (Scroll Left (⇧))'
    (trigger event)
    doesn't map to action
```

## Gimp 2.10

The only difference is that `control + scroll` (^) also produces plain scroll events (second to last)

Text tool: unify all the options in one panel?
Text tool: unify all the options in one panel?
Text tool: unify all the options in one panel?

note.body:
So I took some time to test how things were made in other image editing softwares. Here are my findings.

# [Acorn 5](https://flyingmeat.com/acorn/)

- One side panel (no floating panel)
- Changes to the text options affect only the selection or the text input after modifying the options
- If selecting everything (triple click inside the text block), the panel shows the settings for the first character

# [Pixelmator 3.3](https://www.pixelmator.com/mac/)

- Text options are in a horizontal bar at the top of the canvas
- Changes to the text options affect only the selection or the text input after modifying the options
- If selecting everything, the panel hides settings that are different (see screenshots below)

![Text area in Pixelmator](/uploads/9700792fdaab5eb55efba8cb66356414/acorn.png)
![Text area with selected text in Pixelmator](/uploads/487c96b61e455c25274cb751f963b241/pixelmator.png)

# Photoshop CC (2014)

I didn't have access to a copy of Photoshop but I asked a friend of mine who's a designer and has a copy of it.

- Text options are in a horizontal bar at the top of the canvas
- If selecting text with different properties, the panel hides all settings

# Conclusion

- None of these softwares use a separate text editing toolbar
- The text editing toolbar reflects the properties of the selected text
- If selected text has different properties, text editing toolbar does not show anything (except for Acorn but it looks more a bug than a feature…)

@schumaml What is the rationale in having a separate, on-canvas text editing window?

events.target_title: Text tool: unify all the options in one panel?

note.body:
Bonjour @Jehan, and thanks for your fast feedback!

> Basically being different is no criteria to being worse.

You are right. This is why my conclusion does not mention anything about what to do. It is just a summary of how other softwares are dealing with text. Now that I am writing this, I realize I should have just titled this section “Summary” and not “Conclusion”, my bad!

> But removing it altogether is IMO not a solution. The on-canvas dialog is still very nice as we get the options visually right next to your text. It just needs to be rethought a bit.

I am not a GIMP power user (though I use it quite often for photo editing and to create images or flyers for the family), so I may lack deeper knowledge of the possibilities offered by GIMP, but as far as I know, most, if not all the other tools are controlled from their “Tools options” panel and not from a different (floating) panel.

As you mention, the floating panel suffers from many issues. I have experienced some of the behaviors mentioned in #400, including the fact that a big portion of the panel is not accessible because it's outside of the display area (as shown in the first screenshot of the linked issue).

I was wondering if there was a strong rationale to having this floating panel (this is why I asked @schumaml). Maybe it would be good to ask GIMP users other than us what they think about it and see what we could do about it. I don't know what community would be best to discuss this or create a poll. Would you have any idea?

Finally, in purely technical terms, this floating panel has an additional cost in maintenance and lines of codes in addition to the already existing side panel. If a majority of users don't find it useful, it could be deprecated and that would mean less work for the GIMP developers :)

Thank you for pointing out that this PPA is no longer maintained. I had found the install instructions on [OMG! Ubuntu](https://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2019/02/geary-0-13-released-with-major-improvements), so I sent an e-mail to the author to let him know.

It would be good to put a message in the “PPA description” field of the [page you point to](https://launchpad.net/~geary-team/+archive/ubuntu/releases).

So I tried to follow the official steps from the ["Get it" page](https://wiki.gnome.org/Apps/Geary/GetIt). I installed Flatpak, the software center patch and added FlatHub repo to it. When I click on the link to install Geary, I'm taken on the Software Center, where I learn that the download size is 1 GB (?!!!), but when I try to install it, I get the following error:

I guess I'll stick to Thunderbird for now…

events.target_title: "Inherit theme colors in HTML format" is always visually enabled in composer
"Inherit theme colors in HTML format" is always visually enabled in composer

note.body:
Thanks for the quick reply and sorry for me being late.

Theme inheritance should IMNSHO behave the same in both composer and preview windows. I can see no reason why changing the theme inheritance setting should have no visible effect on the composer window. (While it still, as stated above, does affect the sent messages.)

I do however suspect that this will not be affecting many users, as you need to have a dark theme to be really annoyed by it.

Black on white for composing HTML messages without the setting enabled sounds good, and is as far as I know the de facto standard for any non styled HTML.

I was already aware of the alternative layout, however this isn't what I was looking for.

Since computer screens are generally wider than they are high, distributing long things vertically isn't that great of an idea, so the horizontal layout is better in my opinion.
In the "non-horizontal" layout, the commit panel either robs too much space from the commit graph or isn't high enough to view diffs.

What I would like is being able to switch the commit graph and commit details columns in the horizontal view.

events.target_title: [GTK3.24][Wayland] GtkMenu popup is out of screen when pointer is near screen boundaries
[Wayland] gtk_widget_shape_combine_region makes outside pixels black instead of transparent on Wayland
[GTK3.24][Wayland] GtkMenu popup is out of screen when pointer is near screen boundaries

note.body:
Hi Jonas, 
I observed this issue on GTK3.24 on Fedora 29. On Wayland, the menu always has its corner anchored to the pointer, so when the pointer is near the side of the screen, a lot of the menu items is cutoff. On X11, the menu sometimes has its side touching the pointer to avoid this issue. Maybe the number of items is not enough to observe this issue on your screen, can you try increasing the number of menu items?

note.body:
OK Mike,
Big Thanks! I wasn't aware of the final suggestion's ability. I will also implement the initial, virtual soln. Although I still need to actually fix the laptop's damaged partition table.
I had managed to install 'Boot Repair' on the persistent external, in use SD/Flash & USB Drives; and gave it run yesterday. push_data.commit_title: gmessages: add a new log writer for new-style daemon logging

events.target_title: gmessages: add a new log writer for new-style daemon logging
gmessages: add a new log writer for new-style daemon logging

note.body:
Yes, they're documented at [freedesktop.org](https://www.freedesktop.org/software/systemd/man/daemon.html).

More specifically:
>  Instead of using the syslog() call to log directly to the system syslog service, a new-style daemon may choose to simply log to standard error via fprintf(), which is then forwarded to syslog by the init system. If log levels are necessary, these can be encoded by prefixing individual log lines with strings like "<4>" (for log level 4 "WARNING" in the syslog priority scheme), following a similar style as the Linux kernel's printk() level system. For details, see sd-daemon(3) and systemd.exec(5).

This indeed doesn't allow for structured messages, but it's mostly aimed at simple applications that don't need it anyway. I'm working on a simple GLib-based daemon and had to hand-code this, so thought that it's worth adding it to the core library.

EDIT: another advantage is the code simplification - we don't need any options to switch between logging to terminal or journald - we just always write to stderr.

events.target_title: Trilomix chronogram object add twisted

note.body:
Hello Ed,

If you want to represent this kind off timing diagram: 

[http://www.tij.co.jp/ods/images/SLVSBO3A/RFFE_register_read.gif](http://www.tij.co.jp/ods/images/SLVSBO3A/RFFE_register_read.gif)

You need to do "multiplet" and "non multiplet" in the same chronogram.

So, the "Mutiplet" can do the job but is unable to show "0" or "1". And "Not Multiplet" cannot include data value...
My try was to include the data (twisted) into "Not Multiplet" chronogram.

The way chronogram work is define by the previous state versus the next state.
If you have 2 kind of states you must describe 4 (2^2) transitions.
If you have 3 states (has current release) you must describe 8 (2^3) transitions.
So I had to define 16 (2^4) kind of transitions. As unknown state is needed.
One state is define by 4 points (or 8 points) and one background, one point is define by one x and one y. So (4*2+1) * 16=144 as we double the job for Multiplet 144 * 2=288...

At least I keep compatibility with Multiplet so this double the transitions to describe.

If I optimize the code (reduce the number of line) it's will be harder to understand in my point of view.
I took the time to comment all the transitions so it's "easy" to understand what are doing. One way to optimize the code would be to merge "Multiplet" and "Not Multiplet" transition but it'll be harder to read.

Any thanks to take time to look at my code.

Best regards,

Trilomix

events.target_title: Add login certificate support (client-side SSL certificates)

note.body:
> * Chrome does not expose any UI for client certificates (it is a relatively hidden feature, probably for enterprise)

I'm not sure where this impression is from. I'm using Chrome 73, and I can access the client certificate UI from Settings > Privacy and Security > Manage Certificates. I don't have any enterprise integrations for my browser, either.

events.target_title: Add login certificate support (client-side SSL certificates)

note.body:
>  Its a hidden-ish feature, it doesn't prompt you when a website requires it and by default just fails.

I'm not sure that's fair. The server can request a certificate from the client, but the client doesn't know the effect of not providing one (AFAICT). Some servers will respond with failure, but other servers request client certs promiscuously because these servers offer multiple modes of authentication. I know this is the case because I occasionally see a certificate selection dialog on sites that I don't ever use a client cert with.

This leaves the browser with two choices: (1) assume that a server's request for a client certificate is mandatory, creating confusion or inconvenience for users when it's not or (2) only show the client certificate UI when the user has at least one client certificate configured. I can't blame browsers for choosing the latter, nor would I call it a "hidden UI." It's a choice to show the UI to users likely to use it.

events.target_title: Add login certificate support (client-side SSL certificates)

note.body:
For example, nginx can request client certificates and [treat the request as mandatory or optional](http://nginx.org/en/docs/http/ngx_http_ssl_module.html#ssl_verify_client).

Mandatory: `ssl_verify_client on;`

Optional: `ssl_verify_client optional;`

I don't think the browser knows which was configured, but a refusal to provide a client cert (or simply having none configured) can result in normal responses with the latter configuration.

note.body:
You can set quarantine flags manually, in a terminal:
```
xattr -w com.apple.quarantine "0000;5b0caf3d;Safari.app;" testfile.png
```
Drag `testfile.png` to GIMP, a new process should spawn.

Attribute flags can also be listed with:
```
xattr testfile.png
```

note.body:
Hi.

I had exacly the same issue.

My flatpak intall was brand new, so I thought all was up to date.

Anyway, I ran :
```
~$ flatpak update
Looking for updates...
Installing in system:
org.freedesktop.Platform.ffmpeg/x86_64/1.6 flathub d757f762489e
org.gtk.Gtk3theme.Ambiance/x86_64/3.22     flathub bb7177ca3ed6
org.gnome.Platform.Locale/x86_64/3.28      flathub 0296024b5e1d
Is this ok [y/n]:
```

As you can see, my Platform.Locale needed an update.

After that, Gimp was indeed in my language.

note.body:
It's not really Mutter issue, because my real life case is following:

I have a simple Gtk / gstreamer based media player that needs to load either 800x480 or 800x240 media and this depends on which kind of screen I actually have attached. At the moment, I cannot differentiate between screens because both displays are basically "HDMI-1 / None" :(

Now, what seems to happen at least on KMS/drm the data is received through drm via `drmModeGetProperty`.

events.target_title: Monitor manufacturer/model not properly filled?

note.body:
It's not a Mutter issue, because I use a simple Gtk / gstreamer based media player that loads straight on top of X11 / wayland.

The use case I have is that I need to load a different sized of media, depending on the monitor I have connected and I cannot differentiate between screens because they have both the same resolution and are are identified as "HDMI-1 / None".

I need it eventually, so I will try to cook up something in upcoming months.

events.target_title: Nautilus "Open with" menu missing

note.body: Indeed, I am on Arch. Is that "Open With" dialog not owned by Nautilus? A friend is also experiencing the issue on Ubuntu. Could be a problem with MATE in his case. I'll confirm that with him.

events.target_title: Nautilus "Open with" menu missing

note.body: That's good to know; thank you! Regardless, is there a compelling reason not to have the open-with list appear in the default context menu, as it has in the past?

events.target_title: Nautilus "Open with" menu missing

note.body:
Context menus in general aren't good for touch. It's good that we have a workflow that's touch-friendly, but...
* It isn't my workflow (the workflow that's existed since at least as far back as Windows 95 and is not so much "discovered" as "expected" at this point),
* It's prone to problems in some systems (like the one that caused me to file this bug),
* It's not interfering with the original feature (the "Open with" submenu can still appear right between "open" and "open with other application"),
* It still exposes *exactly* the same context-menu list of applications, but now in EoG (i.e, it's just moved the feature behind my choice of new window: the "Open with other application" window, or an instance of Eye of GNOME),
* Any inconvenience for pointing devices of navigating to a submenu pales in comparison to having to interact with a new window,
* In the case of Eye of GNOME, the user must later go back and *close* that new window after finally opening the file with the desired application.

It's good to have ideals for a system to work toward. But Gimp and InkScape will almost certainly never give me the option of invoking one-another. GNOME can continue to do this, sure, but why is it GNOME's job to provide a previewer for every filetype, if not just to work around the lack of an open-with menu? Or else, why is it Gimp's job (or, as a better example of unexplored frontier, ctmviewer's job) to search the system for other viable applications? This is what I use a file manager for—it's how I browse and open my files. Showing me files and telling an application to open them is its entire job. Nautilus should let me choose EoG or Gimp, ctmviewer or Blender, Totem or Audacity, depending on whether I'm trying to view or edit the file. I think Microsoft adopted "view" and "edit" as separate verbs for this reason.

Maybe opening files with two different apps seems like a corner case, but that's exactly what any kind of specialization in this field is; that infinitely-long tail at the end of the bell curve of people to whom a particular arrangement of bits is exceptionally meaningful. I think it speaks volumes when even the most basic case—images, the case GNOME has currently "solved"—is prone to this sort of problem and is still failing to acknowledge that different editors are all useful at different times.

If we can't just get that menu back, perhaps the application picker could allow me to select other applications that I will open frequently, and treat them as first-class "open with" items, listed between the main "Open" option and the "Open with other application" option. Personally, I'd just put the original submenu there, but as long as it was convenient to add more items there, I wouldn't mind either way.

events.target_title: Nautilus "Open with" menu missing

note.body: I'm on Ubuntu 18.04, Gnome-Flashback, and while I do find having a new window open up to "Open With" an application annoying, it does not automatically change the default program for me.

>  the dialog allows searching and displaying all installed apps

But this was already a feature in earlier versions. It was under the submenu as an option to open the dialog. (I think in Windows Explorer, it's an option under the main menu, which may be less repetitive.)

events.target_title: Dragging icons in dock causes crash and force logout

note.body:
Switching cursor themes solved my issue! I was using Whiteglass as my cursor theme, and switching to Adwaita no longer causes a crash during drag-and-drop on the dock.

I've also switched to the default gnome session just for kicks. And I'm liking it better. Please feel free to close this if there's no further action required.

Thanks guys. I appreciate the help.

note.body: Hi! Just curious if there have been any developments regarding this? I'm one of the users for whom the workaround didn't work and I believe all the asked-for information has been provided.

events.target_title: Scaling Image Interpolation Incorrect or Wrong Result
Scaling Image Interpolation Incorrect or Wrong Result

note.body:
I understand. Doing the steps you mention in Krita does result in a similar looking image (though outlines are a smidge thicker looking still). And of course, the Dalai-Lama picture results in the example given on the page when it is not performed.  

I also do understand that the linear rendering is described as more physically correct and ideal for artists painting, as described from the Krita doc.  
I actually agree with the painting especially, as the smudge brush demonstrates better color mixing.  
Though I still personally prefer the perceptually 'more correct' with respect to the original's proportions and color mixing of the Krita sRGBtrc. I think the linear version (sRGB-elle-V2-g10.icc by default) looks too different especially when displayed side by side on the same screen (LG24MP67HQ with factory calibration).  
I suppose this is a case by case thing for me at this point.  

However doing these manipulations in Krita and trying to find the similarly named options in GIMP has left me with a question.  

When I import this image in GIMP, the Image > Precision displays *8 bit* and *Perceptual sRGB* by default. Should those not be equivalent to the 8 bit sRGB-elle-V2-srgbtrc.icc of Krita (also its default and 'incorrect' option)? From reading the Krita doc, I understood that the sRGBTRC profile was the modified ones better suited to our eye perception but giving the 'incorrect' results.  
In fact, GIMP provides the option of switching to *Linear Light* in the Image > Precision menu, which does lead to visible banding when used with 8 bit, exactly as described in the Krita doc. By changing the bit depth, this banding is obviously solved, from which I infer that a conversion process to a linear space did occur.  

Perhaps you can help me understand what the *8 bit Perceptual sRGB* is supposed to mean in GIMP's case?  
Is it my misunderstanding of what Perceptual/Linear means in different contexts?  
More directly: is it possible for GIMP to render similarly to Krita as in my examples above?  

Thanks again for your time.

events.target_title: Scaling Image Interpolation Incorrect or Wrong Result

note.body:
Thank you for answering my questions.  
If I have anything else, I will keep that forum in mind.

It is unfortunate that GIMP's new version doesn't seem to follow your personal preferences though ;)

>  Personally I would like the ease of being able to instantly switch between linearized and perceptually uniform RGB, for any given editing operation and blend mode. But if my image editor doesn't give me a choice, I don't want my image editor to be automatically and silently modifying my image's RGB values. I'd far rather use an image editor that lets me choose when I want to edit perceptually uniform RGB and when I want to edit using linear gamma RGB.

Again, thank you very much for your time.

events.target_title: g_error does not abort() as documented
g_error does not abort() as documented

note.body:
The `__has_feature(address_sanitizer)` (Clang) or `__SANITIZE_ADDRESS__` (GCC) macros are compile-time checks, but a non-instrumented Glib library could be used with instrumented applications. So this will probably not be usable.

This [post](https://stackoverflow.com/q/3596781/427545) has some ideas for detecting whether the current process is being debugged. Checking `/proc/self/status` for a non-zero `TracerPid` seems a potential solution (this would trap when run under `strace`, `gdb`, `lldb`, etc.). The result should probably not be cached as one can attach/detach a debugger at any point.

(The documentation would definitely need to be updated, explaining when and why SIGTRAP is raised and the motivation/use cases for this behavior.)

events.target_title: g_spawn family does not appear to be safe in multi-threaded programs

note.body:
The potential for deadlock (via `opendir`) is not theoretical, I ran into this while using `g_spawn_sync` in an ASAN-instrumented build. Use of `g_log` (or `g_print`) seems to increase the probability for some reason in some cases.

```
$ clang -g -O2 crap.c $(pkgconf --cflags --libs glib-2.0) -fsanitize=address
$ while date -R; do ./a.out; done
... wait a bit, eventually it will hang ...
```

<details>
<summary>Source code for crap.c</summary>

```c
#include <glib.h>
#include <stdio.h>

void func(gpointer data, gpointer user_data)
{
    guint val = GPOINTER_TO_UINT(data) - 1;
    printf("val %d\n", val);
    // Reproduce:
    g_print("crap:\n");

    char *arg = g_strdup_printf("echo %d", val);
    char *argv[] = { "/bin/echo", arg, NULL };
    char *local_output = NULL;
    int status, exit_status;
    GSpawnFlags flags = 0;
    // Does not help:
    flags |= G_SPAWN_CLOEXEC_PIPES;
    status = g_spawn_sync(NULL, argv, NULL, flags, NULL, NULL,
                          &local_output, NULL, &exit_status, NULL);
    printf("val %d exited with %d/%d and output: %s\n",
            val, status, exit_status, local_output);
    g_free(local_output);
    g_free(arg);
}

int main(void) {
    int max_threads = g_get_num_processors();
    max_threads = 2;    // 2 is the minimum to reproduce (eventually)
    //max_threads = 16;   // make it more likely to hit the condition
    max_threads = 4;
    int t_count = max_threads;
    GThreadPool *pool = g_thread_pool_new(func, NULL, max_threads, FALSE, NULL);
    for (int i = 0; i < t_count; i++) {
        g_thread_pool_push(pool, GUINT_TO_POINTER(i + 1), NULL);
    }
    g_thread_pool_free(pool, FALSE /* immediate */, TRUE /* wait_ */);
    return 0;
}
```
</details>

The parent is waiting for the child and the child is stuck in a lock:

Setting env var `ASAN_OPTIONS=fast_unwind_on_malloc=0` makes this issue even more likely to reproduce. My guess is that these options slow down the malloc call in `opendir` significant enough such that the race condition window becomes larger.

This issue was reproduced with:
- Distribution: Arch Linux
- clang 7.0.0-1
- glib2 2.58.0-412-gc1e44fda6 (and originally in 2.58.1-1)
- glibc 2.28-5

In a `perf trace -o st.txt ./a.out` to trace syscalls (and be able to use GDB to obtain stack traces), I also observed another problem (probably solved on recent kernels with `G_SPAWN_CLOEXEC_PIPES`):
- Thread T1 uses `pipe2()` and gets fds 19, 20.
- Thread T2 forks, inherits fds 19 and 20.
- Thread T1 forks, closes fd 19 and uses 20 for stdout. Child process exits.
- Thread T1 closes 20, reads from 19.
- Thread T1 is now stuck reading because T2 child process still has fd 20 open.

@mcatanzaro Following your recommendation to implement @walters' suggestion to use `getdents64(2)` instead of `opendir(3)`, that would be the second raw user of syscalls (the other being futexes via `__NR_futex`). It would also work for Linux only.

How bad would it be to have a loop to close all file descriptors as suggested in the initial post? (i.e. drop the whole `opendir` optimization from `glib/gspawn.c`?)

Use the Better content blocking rules

note.body:
Hey @aplazas, thank you for opening this issue; makes me feel very welcomed indeed :)

@mcatanzaro First off, wow, man, thank you for your work on Gnome Web. I'm floored by the work of art that is Gnome 3 in general and with the approach and simplicity and ethics of Web.

I was just going to ask whether we could use WebKit content blocker rules instead since the EasyList version is not as expressive/finely-grained. Having those integrated would be awesome.

I'm also planning on reworking how the inspector (crawler/tracker finder) and the builder (the process that creates the web site as well as the content blocker rule lists) with the goal of eventually having the inspector running continuously and integrating into a workflow where anyone can contribute to maintaining the list via an online interface (if only the GitLab interface to begin with).

In any case, I'd love to see this happen and happy to help any way I can. Just let me know what you need/when.

I'm also going to start looking into the codebase and filing some issues so I can dip my toes into possibly helping out with dev a little.

Thank you again for this beautiful contribution to humanity. I haven't been this excited/hopeful about things in a while.

events.target_title: Use the Better content blocking rules

note.body:
>  We should still be cautious in that switching to a new content blocker ruleset brings the risk of overaggressive blocking

This is something Laura and I are very conscious of and work to avoid. That's the reason for the number of (as finely-grained as possible) exceptions to strike a balance between protecting people and not breaking the experience. I think the app store reviews show that we seem to be somewhat meeting that goal :) https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/better-blocker/id1080964978

Also, I'm not sure what AdBlock Plus's spec is but - given that they make millions from adtech/trackers - whatever it is, it is probably best avoided.

note.body:
I _am_ on 2.0.4! I'll look for a repo with older packages.

Found the systemd files due to [this thread](https://bbs.archlinux.org/viewtopic.php?pid=1721443#p1721443):
`/usr/lib/systemd/user/tracker-store.service` and 
`/usr/share/dbus-1/services/org.freedesktop.Tracker1.service`.

```
$ cat /usr/share/dbus-1/services/org.freedesktop.Tracker1.service
[D-BUS Service]
Name=org.freedesktop.Tracker1
Exec=/usr/lib/tracker-store
SystemdService=tracker-store.service
[mark@debiel ~]$ cat /usr/lib/systemd/user/tracker-store.service
[Unit]
Description=Tracker metadata database store and lookup manager

[Service]
Type=dbus
BusName=org.freedesktop.Tracker1
ExecStart=/usr/lib/tracker-store
Restart=on-failure
# Don't restart after tracker daemon -k (aka tracker-control -k)
RestartPreventExitStatus=SIGKILL

```

So I guess that `Restart=on-failure` is the direct cause and the tracker-store quitting with such a error code with the UTF-8 errored image is underlying cause.

You can see that the units are loaded with ` systemctl --user | grep tracker`

events.target_title: wayland: Do not fail on stalled .X11-unix entries

note.body:
Not to me.

```
Aug 21 17:57:51 a gnome-shell[693730]: failed to bind to /tmp/.X11-unix/X0: No such file or directory
Aug 21 17:57:51 a gnome-shell[693730]: failed to bind to /tmp/.X11-unix/X1: No such file or directory
Aug 21 17:57:51 a gnome-shell[693730]: failed to bind to /tmp/.X11-unix/X2: No such file or directory

***58184 lines removed

Aug 21 17:58:22 a gnome-shell[693730]: failed to bind to /tmp/.X11-unix/X765663: No such file or directory
Aug 21 17:58:22 a gnome-shell[693730]: failed to bind to /tmp/.X11-unix/X765664: No such file or directory
Aug 21 17:58:22 a gnome-shell[693730]: failed to bind to /tmp/.X11-unix/X765665: No such file or directory
```

Problem is I have in /etc/security/namespace.conf 
`/tmp            /tmp/tmp-inst/          user    root,adm`
and gdm+friends do not take into account that gnome-shell should actually be looking at
`/tmp/tmp-inst/safari/.X11-unix` instead.

Lightdm+mate works OK (without wayland), mate-session uses ```/tmp/tmp-inst/safari/.ICE-unix/xyz```.
Wayland support would be nice if it was backwards compatible with established standards (like namespace.conf).
